trustfund:
TF032718-POLAND - FOREST BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF031280-POLAND -FORESTRY BIODIVERSITY PROTECTION,TF021685-GET-FOREST BIODIVERSITY
            PROTECTION PROJ.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Forest Biodiversity
            Protection Project for Poland were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, project sustainability was likely, Bank
            performance during implementation was also satisfactory, and
            the recipient's performance was more satisfactory
            during appraisal and implementation than during
            identification and preparation. Some lessons learned
            included: the project was intended to test a balance of
            in-situ and ex-situ conservation, depending upon the
            imminence of the threat on the environment. To date, it has
            demonstrated that in-situ conservation is more
            cost-effective than ex-situ conservation, and that the time
            horizon of the threat and outside social and economic forces
            are factors to consider when allocating scarce resources.
            Furthermore, it teaches that without directly linking
            in-situ restoration activities to ex-situ conservation, the
            usefulness of the latter is jeopardized. The project
            suffered from a lack of proactive, thoughtful
            outreach/public relation activities at local as well as
            national level. It must be recognized, however, that at the
            local level, after a certain resistance was overcome, the
            project was able to generate some important support for
            Bialowieza Primeval Forest (BPF) through outreach activities
            like man and the biosphere.
